Case: James-Lanier-MVA-6-28-2025
Client: James Lanier

From: Jim Lanier
Sent: Wednesday, August 27, 2025 7:34 AM
To: Justin
Subject: RE: Quick Update as of 8/27
Good morning Justin,
Quick update:
• Dr Schertzinger (OrthoCincy) put me
on tramadol for the pain.
• Dr told me no upper body exercises
until inflammation and pain reduces
significantly. Will revisit on 9/10 at
follow up appointment
• I have a scheduled appointment with
an OrthoCincy shoulder specialist, Dr
Velasquez on Tuesday, 9/2 to receive
a PRP shot in my shoulder. I will be
requesting a Good Faith Estimate for
what costs to expect with PRP
shot treatments moving forward.
• Consultation scheduled for 10/7 with
OrthoCincy shoulder surgeon, Dr
Greiwe to discuss options
for surgery and receive Good Faith
Estimate for all surgery options.
• Consultation scheduled with
Cincinnati Reds Ortho Specialist on
10/15 to discuss Stem Cell Therapy
treatment and receive Good Faith
Estimate.
Please let me know if you have any questions. Once I receive the Good Faith Estimates and any additional bills, I will send to you ASAP and we can discuss any additional updates and/ or next steps.
Best Regards,
Jim Lanier
513-288-8834
episodes.natural_language:
Case: James-Lanier-MVA-6-28-2025. Client: James Lanier. On August 27, 2025, Jim Lanier sent an update to Justin regarding his motor vehicle accident recovery. He reported that Dr. Schertzinger at OrthoCincy has started him on tramadol for pain. The doctor advised that he should avoid any upper-body exercises until inflammation and pain decrease significantly, with a follow-up appointment to revisit his progress on September 10.

Lanier also noted several upcoming visits. He has a scheduled appointment with OrthoCincy shoulder specialist Dr. Velasquez on Tuesday, September 2, to receive a PRP shot in his shoulder, and he will request a Good Faith Estimate to outline anticipated costs for PRP treatments moving forward. A consultation is planned for October 7 with OrthoCincy shoulder surgeon Dr. Greiwe to discuss surgical options and obtain a Good Faith Estimate for all surgery options.

Additionally, there is a consultation scheduled with the Cincinnati Reds orthopedic specialist on October 15 to discuss Stem Cell Therapy treatment and to receive a Good Faith Estimate. Lanier concluded by asking Justin to let him know if there are any questions. He stated that once he receives the Good Faith Estimates and any additional bills, he will send them ASAP and will discuss any further updates or next steps. Best regards, Jim Lanier, 513-288-8834.
episodes.author: Aaron

episodes.original_body:
Case: James-Lanier-MVA-6-28-2025
Client: James Lanier

From: justin@whaleylawfirm.com
To: 'Aaron Whaley' agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com
Date: Wed Aug 20 2025 09:54:51 GMT-04:00
See below. Sounds like the Ortho is willing to do a narrative report for client, who has 2 labral tears, but appears he wants to charge for them. Think it’s worth it or should I just send a normal request for records?
Alabama accident, unsure of BI limits at this point.
From: Jim Lanier
Sent: Wednesday, August 20, 2025 8:56 AM
To: Justin
Subject: RE: Letter of request for medical bills, treatment, diagnosis, & recommendations
Good morning Justin,
Please see Dr Schertzinger’s response to my letter of request for medical bills, treatment, diagnosis and recommendations.
Dr Schertzinger's response:
“Yes during office hours at a time convenient for you is best for documentation. Our treatment plan is the same as I outlined with you several days ago HIPPA allows you access to all your medical records. Ask your attorney to send a letter to me outlining his/her requests to which I will send the medical narrative after receipt of my compensation. Been working for 34 years and you’re not the first to make this request.”
Please send your letter of request to Dr Schertzinger outlining everything he mentioned above along with all of the details you need and he will provide everything to you. You can send the letter addressed to:
HOWARD J. SCHERTZINGER, JR, MD
2626 Alexandria Pike
Highland Heights, KY 41076
Please confirm receipt of this email. I want to avoid any potential delays.
Best regards,
Jim Lanier
513-288-8834
episodes.natural_language:
Case: James-Lanier-MVA-6-28-2025. Client: James Lanier.

On June 28, 2025, James Lanier was involved in a motor vehicle accident in Alabama. At this stage, the bodily injury (BI) limits of the other party are unknown.

On August 20, 2025, Justin from the Whaley law firm emailed Aaron Whaley with a note about the orthopedist. He observed that the orthopedic doctor is apparently willing to prepare a narrative report for the client, who has two labral tears, but that the doctor appears to want to charge for the report. Justin asked whether it is worth pursuing the narrative report or if a normal request for medical records should be sent instead. He also noted the Alabama accident and that BI limits were still unclear.

Earlier that same day, at 8:56 AM, Jim Lanier replied to Justin with Dr. Schertzinger’s response to Lanier’s prior letter requesting medical bills, treatment, diagnosis, and recommendations. Lanier relayed Dr. Schertzinger’s reply: “Yes during office hours at a time convenient for you is best for documentation. Our treatment plan is the same as I outlined with you several days ago HIPPA allows you access to all your medical records. Ask your attorney to send a letter to me outlining his/her requests to which I will send the medical narrative after receipt of my compensation. Been working for 34 years and you’re not the first to make this request.”

Lanier then instructed Justin to send a letter of request to Dr. Schertzinger that outlines everything mentioned above along with all of the details needed, and that Dr. Schertzinger would provide everything after receipt of compensation. He provided the recipient address as: HOWARD J. SCHERTZINGER, JR, MD, 2626 Alexandria Pike, Highland Heights, KY 41076. Lanier also asked Justin to confirm receipt of the email to avoid potential delays and signed off with his contact number: 513-288-8834.
episodes.author: Aaron

episodes.original_body:
Case: James-Lanier-MVA-6-28-2025
Client: James Lanier

From: Jim Lanier
Sent: Tuesday, August 19, 2025 5:19 PM
To: Justin (Attorney)
Subject: RE: Progressive knows that in Alabama it’s all or nothing…
Justin,
Of course Progressive is trying to argue that their client was 100% not at fault. I'm sure that you are aware that in Alabama, the scene of the accident, “shared fault” in rear-end collision claims are governed by the legal doctrine of contributory negligence, meaning that if you are even 1% at fault for the accident, you are barred from recovering any damages whatsoever, even if the other driver was primarily responsible, according to legal resources. This strict standard makes proving fault in rear-end collisions crucial for obtaining compensation in Alabama.
I can prove that I provided enough time and space to responsibly stop in a manner to remain safe and not collide with the car in front of me. The car behind me cannot say the same nor can they prove that they were prudent in providing the same level of care as I did to provide enough time and space to successfully avoid hitting me. Hence, they were clearly negligent.
We were traveling at about 50 mph. If the driver had provided 5 car lengths of distance between my car and theirs, then they could have successfully avoided hitting me and my family from behind.
The indisputable fact is that the driver’s speed, lack of distance between their car and mine, and lack of good judgement left the driver negligent from doing everything possible to successfully avoid hitting me and my family from behind.
The other indisputable fact is that if the driver did use good judgement, and the driver did leave enough time and space, and the driver did do everything possible to avoid a collision, then there would have been zero chance of the driver ever hitting me.
Best Regards,
Jim Lanier
513-288-8834
episodes.natural_language:
Case: James-Lanier-MVA-6-28-2025. Client: James Lanier.

In an email dated Tuesday, August 19, 2025 at 5:19 PM, from Jim Lanier to Justin (Attorney), the subject line RE: Progressive knows that in Alabama it’s all or nothing…, Lanier discusses Progressive’s position in a motor vehicle accident case. He notes that Progressive is arguing that their client was 100% not at fault. He reminds that in Alabama, the scene of the accident, “shared fault” in rear-end collision claims is governed by the doctrine of contributory negligence, meaning that if you are even 1% at fault, you are barred from recovering any damages whatsoever, even if the other driver was primarily responsible, according to legal resources. He explains that this strict standard makes proving fault in rear-end collisions crucial for obtaining compensation in Alabama.

Lanier states that he can prove he provided enough time and space to responsibly stop in a manner to remain safe and not collide with the car in front of him. He asserts that the car behind him cannot say the same nor can they prove that they were prudent in providing the same level of care as he did to provide enough time and space to successfully avoid hitting him. Hence, he contends, they were clearly negligent. They were traveling at about 50 mph. If the driver behind had provided five car lengths of distance between his car and theirs, then they could have successfully avoided hitting Lanier and his family from behind.

Lanier presents what he calls indisputable facts: the driver’s speed, lack of distance between their car and his, and lack of good judgement left the driver negligent for not doing everything possible to successfully avoid hitting him and his family from behind. He also states another indisputable fact: if the driver had used good judgement, left enough time and space, and done everything possible to avoid a collision, there would have been zero chance of the driver ever hitting him.

Best regards,
Jim Lanier
513-288-8834
episodes.author: Aaron

about.relevance: insurer taking position that their client was not at fault
alleged negligent party in rear-end collision

episodes.original_body:
Case: James-Lanier-MVA-6-28-2025
Client: James Lanier

Hello Justin,

I have been informed by my orthopedic surgeon that I require shoulder surgery due to the significant damage from my auto accident. Given my age, the success rate for repairable surgery is under 40%. Therefore, my doctor recommends debridement surgery to remove dead tissue from the torn labrum, which will aid in the growth of healthy tissue and improve shoulder function. My doctor is also concerned about my ongoing severe neck muscle spasms and has scheduled an MRI to assess my neck. The MRI results will dictate the timing of my shoulder surgery. The cost estimate provided by my doctor shows that this type of surgery will cost approximately $17,000 and will provide you with that documentation.

I would like to set up a brief call with you to discuss further.
episodes.natural_language:
Case: James-Lanier-MVA-6-28-2025. Client: James Lanier.

Initial client contact on June 28, 2025, with James Lanier regarding a motor vehicle accident. In a message addressed to Justin, Lanier begins with “Hello Justin” and explains that he has been informed by his orthopedic surgeon that he requires shoulder surgery due to significant damage from the auto accident.

Lanier states that, given his age, the success rate for repairable shoulder surgery is under 40%. Consequently, his doctor recommends debridement surgery to remove dead tissue from the torn labrum, which is intended to aid in the growth of healthy tissue and improve shoulder function.

He adds that his doctor is also concerned about ongoing severe neck muscle spasms and has scheduled an MRI to assess his neck. The MRI results will dictate the timing of the shoulder surgery.

The cost estimate from his doctor indicates that this type of surgery will cost approximately $17,000, and the doctor will provide that documentation.

Lanier concludes by stating his desire to set up a brief call to discuss further.
episodes.author: James Lanier

episodes.original_body:
Case: James-Lanier-MVA-6-28-2025
Client: James Lanier

**FILE ORGANIZATION COMPLETED - James Lanier Case**

Completed comprehensive 5-phase file organization using Case File Organization skill with 8-bucket system and content-based naming:

**Phase 1 - Inventory:** Generated inventory of 65 files, scrambled 16 .md filenames to eliminate naming bias, created PDF-MD mapping.

**Phase 2 - Analysis & Mapping:** Parallel processing with 6 sub-agents (43 files > 40 threshold), created reorganization map for 47 files, identified 1 duplicate.

**Phase 3 - Quality Review:** Error rate 18.75% (3 errors/16 files), identified 2 additional missed duplicates, main agent approved corrections.

**Phase 4 - Execution:** Moved 23 files (11 PDF+MD pairs, 1 image) to 8-bucket structure, deleted 3 duplicates, reunified PDFs with .md companions.

**Phase 5 - Verification:** 100% naming convention compliance, 100% PDF+MD companion matching, 35 files organized (54% of total), 27 files remain in root for manual review.

**Result:** Case file 54% organized with core documents properly categorized. Quality metrics: 81.25% initial accuracy, 100% after corrections.
episodes.natural_language:
The James-Lanier-MVA-6-28-2025 case, involving client James Lanier, completed a comprehensive five-phase file organization using Case File Organization skills, an eight-bucket structure, and content-based naming.

In Phase 1, an inventory of 65 files was generated. To eliminate naming bias, 16 Markdown (.md) filenames were scrambled, and a PDF-to-MD mapping was created.

Phase 2 involved analysis and mapping with parallel processing by six sub-agents handling 43 files that exceeded the 40-file threshold. A reorganization map was created for 47 files, and one duplicate was identified.

Phase 3 carried out a quality review with an error rate of 18.75% (3 errors in 16 files). Two additional missed duplicates were identified, and the main agent approved the corrections.

During Phase 4, 23 files were moved into the eight-bucket structure (comprising 11 PDF+MD pairs and 1 image). Three duplicates were deleted, and PDFs were reunified with their MD companions.

Phase 5 verified 100% naming convention compliance and 100% PDF+MD companion matching. A total of 35 files were organized, representing 54% of the total, while 27 files remained in the root directory for manual review.

Resulting from these efforts, the case file is 54% organized with core documents properly categorized. Quality metrics were 81.25% initial accuracy and 100% accuracy after corrections.
episodes.author: Roscoe (AI Paralegal)

about.relevance: case client / subject of file organization
